title: Are popular Quorans ever accused of writing fake answers? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t know if I count as a popular Quoran, but I’ve definitely been accused (mostly in the comments) of making up stories, or exaggerating them greatly. First off- I have never made up a story or lied about something happening. I may have exaggerated some small things, but not the thing that people assume I exaggerated. I certainly never exaggerate the aspect that has to do with answering the question. For example: I once answered a question about a sexist encounter. I gave my answer about an extremely sexist man that I once met, who genuinely believed that women “should be seen and not heard.” I was accused of making up, or at least exaggerating, how sexist he was in order to get more upvotes. The man himself was true as blue. I don’t think I could have exaggerated him if I tried. That’s why I remember him so well to this day, he was more sexist than any other person I’ve ever met. It was mind-boggling how much he believed that women were “less than” men. However, I did “exaggerate” the condition under which I met him, in order to shorten the answer and not go into a long, boring story about how he was in a group that I was assigned to, as part of a Communications class. I think, in the answer itself, I just said that I met him in college and that after a single conversation, we decided that we wanted nothing to do with each other. This is technically true, but in real life, I actually had to deal with this person until our group project was complete. Also, all the stories I say are from my personal point of view. As we know, human memories are predictably unreliable. I tell stories from my past, from my experience, how I remember them. Someone else who was there may remember it quite differently, especially the further back you go.

I have, a couple of times. Once, I discussed the background of my concern about gun regulation issues, telling the story of a friend of my mother, who lost both her sons in a tragedy due to their access to a home firearm. I got a ridiculous and rabid denunciation from someone who claimed that I had falsified the story. I only wish I had. I am still haunted by the look of grief on that woman’s face afterward, and she had been so radiant before. Another time was my recounting an incident from my time working at the Department of Justice. Someone accused me of plagiarism. The accusation was absurd. Nevertheless, I was reported to Quora Moderation and required to edit my response. There have been occasions where people gave rumblings that I exaggerate about Napster’s massiveness, but now that I’ve posted pictures of him, those challengers have conceded that they were wrong. (Don’t ask me for more pictures; I use my iPhone, and I get a surcharge on my data plan when I try to demand that many pixels.)

I have been, on several occasions. I've been accused of making up stories about how I lost my virginity (yes, my first sexual experience really was a threesome) and about going from socially awkward to the person I am now (one Quora user claimed that you're born with social skills, they're not learned, and I was being mean to socially awkward teenagers by making up stories about going from social awkwardness to social confidence). On a couple of occasions, I've been accused of lying about being polyamorous. One particular Quoran, now banned, followed me about for a while telling me I was a pathetic liberal beta cuck who could never get laid, and I made up stories about multiple girlfriends to make myself feel better. This despite the fact that a couple of my partners (Joreth and Eve) are on Quora.

Do I qualify as popular on Quora? I don't really know. But I have been accused of lying 6-12 times. On one occassion the person repeated the accusation each time I cited support references. Maybe 5 times? I eventually told him to refute my posts and stop calling me a liar or I would delete the whole conversation. He responded: “Go ahead. Delete me. Your still a liar.” No amount of supporting my position would even convince him to be civil. So I deleted the conversation. I may have blocked him. I don't have to tolerate being called a liar.

No, or at least I'm not. I think most of my followers understand that since I have to hide so many things in real life, this is my only outlet to really be me. I have to lie about myself on a day to day basis, so why would I not take this as an opportunity to tell the truth?

Well, I've never been. People are always talking about how honest I come off, because, well, I am honest in my replies. I've been offered money to write fake answers promoting some blog or product or whatever, though. Haven't done it. Are popular quorans ever accused of writing fake answers?

I have a habit of reading through all the comments on answers I either like or find troubling. Quora has made this difficult recently by concealing the comment section or inserting more “read more” buttons than are useful, so I suspect that most people don’t bother. I have an outsider’s perspective here: the popular Quorans probably don’t even notice when people accuse them of anything, because they get so many notifications. Some of them make an effort to keep on top of it, but most will answer at most the first couple of comments before giving up. Popular Quorans probably read their comments a lot less than regular users. I follow a couple of popular Quorans and see them occasionally get accused of making things up. Most of the time I don’t think they reply. The accusations I’ve seen are only occasionally valid. More often than not they come across as trollish or sour grapes. Sometimes they’re just irrelevant - if someone is adding nonsense comments to random answers, it’s going to be more visible on a popular user’s content.

I’m in the kinda-sorta-popular range and I’ve been accused a handful of times. Admittedly, when you write about ridiculousness…people are going to be suspect. It doesn’t matter that most of what I write about makes me look like a serious jerk with a bad habit of getting bodily excretion on himself (I think I know what will go on my dating profile), I can understand it. I have to be honest that I'm surprised I haven't been confronted more often than I have.

I'm far from popular but I was accused by one Quoran that said I had answered my own (“stupid”) question to get upvotes. She thought I hijacked my own question with my own answer that went viral. Umm… ain't nobody got time for that. Can you imagine? Formulating an answer that will go viral by formulating a question? I have no clue if or when one of my answers go viral; some of my answers just do, but a tonne more don't even hit close to 100 upvotes. I'm lucky if I even get an upvote! I can't plan for that. There's no secret formula to follow. I mean there sort of is, but it in no way can determine if an answer will gain attention. I try to write a captivating answer, then as Ronco says, “set it and forget it!”

A new person to Quora might notice that among some readers there is a certain density to their mind set. Many popular Quorans like to sprinkle a little humor, sarcasm and anecdotes in their answers, because there are a lot of questions being submitted which are pretty ridiculous. Answering such questions with subtle, but just as ridiculous sarcasm, is rather fun once in awhile. I find some of these “fake answers” hilarious. It is equally amazing that some readers take them seriously, and call them fake answers to clearly leading questions.

Yes, on a lot of occasions. Forget popular Quorans, even celebrities in real life have been accused of creating fake stories about their lives. Oprah Winfrey has been accused of fabricating the extreme poverty that she grew up in during her childhood. Which has allegedly been corroborated by either her sister or one of her close friends.

Define Fake Answer. I have read some non-answers yes, For example, I sometimes read the question several times trying to figure out “Is this the question, or did the askers grammar, punctuation or native language unintentionally re-phrase the question, I usually just end up answering the question as asked.

In an odd twist, I have been gently admonished because I wrote something that was fiction, but people wanted it to be true! Go over the comments, and you’ll see what I mean. John Geare's answer to How do I prove to people in 2017 that I'm a time traveller from 3060? Hope that helps.

I have. And sometimes people are quite rude about it. Often it’s when I insert something in a response that someone doesn’t want to believe (e.g.: in many ways gasoline is far more dangerous than hydrogen as an automotive fuel). Man, that one really brought out the crazies. I was attacked for days by people who clearly had no idea what they were talking about.

Thanks for the A2A Julian Frank, some Quorans do in fact get accused of lying because of the stories they tell. Some events which occur in their daily life seem farfetched and made up in some instances, especially if they are teenagers.
Only once. When I wrote an answer regarding the $10,000,000 lawsuit I fought one person wrote something to the effect of “This is clearly a made up story, I smell Asbergers”. Huh?
I plan on being on Quora under a pen-name and giving wrong answers constantly. Terribly wrong answers that hopefully will be hilarious.
